datasets.title: Datasets
datasets.description: Upload and manage datasets for your current project
datasets.uploadArea: Drag & drop your dataset files here, or click to browse
datasets.tip1: Remember column names at the top of the CSV file.
datasets.tip2: It's best to upload CSV files separated by commas, semicolons, tabs, or spaces.
datasets.invalidFileFormat: Invalid file format. Only .csv or .zip files are allowed

notFound.title: Page not found
notFound.description: Sorry, we couldn't find the page you're looking for.

help.title: Help & Support
help.subtitle: Find answers, get help, and learn more about Maid
help.noFAQResults: No FAQ items found matching your search.

faq.q1: How do I create a new project?
faq.a1: Click the 'Create project' button in the My Projects section and fill out the form with the project name and description.
faq.q2: What file formats are supported for datasets?
faq.a2: We support CSV files and compressed ZIP files containing CSV files.
faq.q3: How can I make my project public?
faq.a3: In the project settings, toggle the visibility switch from Private to Public. You can do this in the sidebar when editing your project.
faq.q4: How do I delete my account?
faq.a4: Go to Profile Settings and scroll to the Danger Zone section where you'll find the option to delete your account.
faq.q5: How do I run calculations in a project?
faq.a5: After saving changes in your project, click the 'Run calculations' button in the top bar. Make sure you've selected the appropriate X and Y columns and regression algorithm.
faq.q6: Can I edit a project I viewed from the home page?
faq.a6: No, projects visible on the home page can only be viewed and have calculations run. Editing is only possible for your own projects available in the My Projects section.
faq.q7: How do I select the appropriate columns for calculations?
faq.a7: First, select a dataset for your project. The system will then automatically load available columns. Select the X column (independent variable) and Y column (dependent variable) from the dropdown list.
faq.a8: The system supports various regression algorithms, including linear regression, Ridge regression, and others. Available options depend on the data type and selected parameters.
faq.q9: How do I change the project status?
faq.a9: In the project editing sidebar, you'll find the 'Status' field. You can choose between statuses: Draft, Active, or Completed.
faq.q10: Can I change the dataset assigned to a project?
faq.a10: Yes, in the project editing sidebar you can select a different dataset from the list of available datasets. Remember that changing the dataset may require reselecting columns.
faq.q11: What do the different project statuses mean?
faq.a11: Draft - project is being created, Active - project is ready for use, Completed - project has been finished.
faq.q12: How do I add a dataset to favorites?
faq.a12: On the datasets page, click the heart icon next to the selected dataset to add it to favorites. You must be logged in to use this feature.

inference.pasteJsonInstruction: Paste an array of arrays or an object that contains

train.saveGraphFirst: Please save the model graph first (Canvas > Save).
train.prepareDataset: Please prepare the dataset in the Dataset tab before training.
train.noTargetColumn: Target column is not set in Dataset preprocessing.
train.title: Training Configuration

cannotStart.title: Cannot start training:
cannotStart.graphNotCompiled: Model graph is not compiled. Go to the Canvas tab and compile your model.
cannotStart.datasetNotPrepared: Dataset is not prepared. Go to the Dataset tab and load/preprocess your data.

optimizer.label: Optimizer
optimizer.help: Controls how weights update during training. Adam is a solid default; SGD can work well with momentum for large datasets.

gradientClipping.label: Gradient Clipping (clipnorm)
gradientClipping.help: Clips gradients by norm to prevent exploding gradients. Leave empty to disable.

lossFunction.label: Loss Function
lossFunction.help: Must match your problem and label format: regression (MSE/MAE), binary (BinaryCrossentropy), multiclass (Categorical or SparseCategorical Crossentropy), etc.

hint.classMismatch: Heads up: target looks like classification but a regression loss is selected. Consider sparse_categorical_crossentropy (integer labels) or categorical_crossentropy (one-hot), or binary_crossentropy for 2 classes.
hint.regMismatch: Heads up: target looks continuous but a classification loss is selected. Consider mse/mae for regression.

epochs.label: Epochs
epochs.help: One epoch = one full pass over the training data. More epochs can improve fit but risk overfitting. Use EarlyStopping to stop automatically.

batchSize.label: Batch Size
batchSize.help: Samples per gradient step. Larger batches are faster but may generalize worse; smaller batches add noise that can help generalization.

learningRate.label: Learning rate (optional)
learningRate.help: Step size for weight updates. Too high can diverge; too low can be slow. Typical values: 1e-3 to 1e-4 for Adam.

valBatchSize.label: Validation batch size (optional)
valBatchSize.help: If empty, uses the training batch size. Only affects validation throughput, not training dynamics.

shuffle.label: Shuffle training data each epoch
shuffle.help: Recommended. Prevents learning spurious order; disable only for sequence-sensitive data already batched in order.

saveBestModel.label: Save Best Model
saveBestModel.disabledNote: Disabled because "Restore best weights" is active. The final model will already be the best model.

earlyStopping.label: EarlyStopping
earlyStopping.help: Stop training when a monitored metric stops improving. Helps avoid overfitting and saves time.

restoreBest.label: Restore best weights
restoreBest.help: After stopping, roll back to the best-performing epoch.

reduceLr.label: ReduceLROnPlateau
reduceLr.help: Reduce the learning rate when a metric has stopped improving to fine-tune training.
reduceLr.metricHelp: Metric used to decide when to reduce the learning rate.
reduceLr.factorHelp: Multiplicative drop. Example: 0.1 will change 1e-3 to 1e-4.
reduceLr.patienceHelp: How many epochs with no improvement before reducing the learning rate.

metricsShowing.classification: Showing metrics suitable for classification (based on selected loss).
metricsShowing.regression: Showing metrics suitable for regression (based on selected loss).

metrics.watchHelp: Which metric to watch. For classification, prefer a relevant accuracy; for regression, use val_loss/loss.
metrics.chooseModeHelp: Choose "min" for losses (lower is better) and "max" for accuracies (higher is better). "auto" infers it.
metrics.patienceHelp: How many epochs with no improvement before stopping.
metrics.minDeltaHelp: Minimum change to qualify as an improvement (helps ignore tiny fluctuations).

job.title: Training Job
job.noJobYet: No job yet. Configure parameters on the left and click "Start Training" to begin.

instructions.title: Instructions
instructions.buttonTooltip: View step-by-step instructions for using this tab

overview.title: Model Canvas Overview
overview.description: The Model Canvas is your visual workspace for building neural networks. Think of it as a flowchart where you connect different building blocks (layers) to create your AI model. No coding required!
overview.imagePlaceholder: Screenshot of the canvas with layers connected

gettingStarted.title: Getting Started
gettingStarted.step1: Look at the left sidebar - you'll see available layers like Input, Dense, Dropout, etc.
gettingStarted.step2: Drag a layer from the sidebar and drop it onto the canvas.
gettingStarted.step3: Click on any layer to configure its parameters in the right panel.
gettingStarted.step4: Connect layers by dragging from one layer's output to another's input.
gettingStarted.step5: Click 'Compile' in the toolbar to validate your model architecture.

layers.title: Understanding Layers
layers.description: Each layer type serves a specific purpose, for example:
layers.input: The entry point for your data. Set the shape to match your dataset features.
layers.dense: Fully connected layer - the workhorse of neural networks. Great for learning patterns.
layers.conv2d: Convolutional layer for image data. Detects patterns like edges and shapes.
layers.maxpool: Reduces data size while keeping important features. Often used after Conv2D.
layers.dropout: Randomly 'turns off' neurons during training to prevent overfitting.
layers.flatten: Converts multi-dimensional data to 1D. Required before Dense layers in CNNs.
layers.batchnorm: Normalizes layer outputs for faster, more stable training.

tips.title: Pro Tips
tips.tip1: Always start with an Input layer and match its shape to your data.
tips.tip2: For tabular data, use Dense layers. For images, start with Conv2D.
tips.tip3: Add Dropout (0.2-0.5) between Dense layers to prevent overfitting.
tips.tip4: Use the Compile button frequently to catch architecture errors early.

toolbar.title: Toolbar Actions
toolbar.saveDesc: Save your model to your account for later use.
toolbar.compileDesc: Validate your model and check for errors.
toolbar.importExportDesc: Import Keras or graph JSON or export your model as Python code.

overview.title: Model Summary Overview
overview.description: The Model Summary tab shows you the complete architecture of your neural network in a table format, including layer types, output shapes, and parameter counts.

howToUse.title: How to Use
howToUse.step1: First, build your model in the Canvas tab with all layers connected.
howToUse.step2: Click 'Generate Summary' to compile and analyze your model.
howToUse.step3: Review the table to understand your model's structure and complexity.

understanding.title: Understanding the Summary
understanding.layerTypeDesc: The name and type of each layer in order of data flow.
understanding.outputShapeDesc: The dimensions of data after passing through this layer. 'None' represents batch size.
understanding.paramsDesc: The number of trainable parameters (weights and biases) in this layer.

tips.title: What to Look For
tips.tip1: Total parameters affect training time and memory usage - millions of params need more data.
tips.tip2: Check output shapes to ensure data flows correctly through your network.
tips.tip3: If you see unexpected shapes, verify your layer configurations.

overview.title: Dataset Manager Overview
overview.description: The Dataset tab is where you prepare your data for training. Good data preparation is crucial for model performance - this is often more important than the model architecture itself!
overview.imagePlaceholder: Screenshot of dataset manager with data preview

uploading.title: Loading Your Data
uploading.step1: Click 'Choose CSV File' to upload a local CSV file, or 'Load from Database' if you have saved datasets.
uploading.step2: Your data will be displayed in a preview table showing the first rows.
uploading.step3: The system automatically detects column types (numeric, categorical, etc.).

columnConfig.title: Column Configuration
columnConfig.description: For each column, assign a role:
columnConfig.featureDesc: Input variables the model will learn from (e.g., age, income, measurements).
columnConfig.targetDesc: The value you want to predict. You must select exactly one target column.
columnConfig.ignoreDesc: Columns to exclude from training (e.g., ID columns, names).

preprocessing.title: Data Preprocessing
preprocessing.description: Configure how your data should be transformed before training:
preprocessing.labelEncoding: Label Encoding: Converts categories to numbers (Cat=0, Dog=1, Bird=2).
preprocessing.oneHotEncoding: One-Hot Encoding: Creates separate columns for each category (better for unordered categories).
preprocessing.missingDesc: How to handle missing data - fill with mean/median/mode or remove rows.
preprocessing.standard: Standard Scaling (Z-score): Centers data around 0 with standard deviation of 1.
preprocessing.minmax: Min-Max Scaling: Scales values to range [0, 1].

splitting.title: Data Splitting
splitting.description: Your data is split into three sets:
splitting.trainDesc: Used to teach the model (majority of data).
splitting.validationDesc: Used to tune hyperparameters and prevent overfitting.
splitting.testDesc: Used for final evaluation - never seen during training.

important.title: Important Notes
important.warning1: You MUST select a target column before processing.
important.warning2: Click 'Process Dataset' after configuring all settings.
important.warning3: The green 'Ready for Training' badge indicates your data is prepared.

overview.title: Training Configuration Overview
overview.description: This is where you configure how your neural network learns. Training is the process where the model adjusts its weights by learning from your data.

beforeTraining.title: Before You Start
beforeTraining.req1: Model is compiled (Canvas tab → Compile button shows success).
beforeTraining.req2: Dataset is processed (Dataset tab shows 'Ready for Training').
beforeTraining.req3: Target column is correctly set in dataset preprocessing.

compilation.title: Compilation Settings
compilation.optimizerDesc: Controls how the model updates weights. 'adam' is a great default that works well for most cases.
compilation.lossRegression: For regression (predicting numbers): examples include MeanSquaredError (MSE) or MeanAbsoluteError (MAE).
compilation.lossMulticlass: For multiple classes: Use 'CategoricalCrossentropy' (one-hot labels) or 'SparseCategoricalCrossentropy' (integer labels).

hyperparameters.title: Training Parameters
hyperparameters.epochsDesc: Number of times the model sees the entire dataset. Start with 10-50, increase if needed.
hyperparameters.batchSizeDesc: Number of samples processed before updating weights. 32 is a good default.
hyperparameters.learningRateDesc: How big each learning step is. Leave empty for optimizer default (usually 0.001).

callbacks.title: Callbacks (Optional)
callbacks.earlyStoppingDesc: Stops training when the model stops improving, preventing wasted time and overfitting.
callbacks.reduceLrDesc: Automatically decreases learning rate when learning stalls, helping escape local minima.

train.metricsBlurb: The metrics you pick here determine which charts and values appear in the Metrics tab after training finishes - use that tab to compare loss, validation loss, accuracy, and other relevant scores.

tips.title: Training Tips
tips.tip1: Start with default settings and adjust based on results.
tips.tip2: Watch the validation loss - if it increases while training loss decreases, you're overfitting.
tips.tip3: Enable Early Stopping for longer training runs to save time.
tips.tip4: Check the Metrics tab after training to evaluate model performance.

overview.title: Metrics Dashboard Overview
overview.description: The Metrics tab displays detailed results after training completes. Use these visualizations to understand how well your model learned and whether it generalizes to new data.
overview.imagePlaceholder: Screenshot of metrics dashboard with charts

keyMetrics.title: Key Metrics Explained
keyMetrics.lossDesc: Measures how wrong the model's predictions are. Lower is better. Should decrease over epochs.
keyMetrics.accuracyDesc: Percentage of correct predictions (for classification). Higher is better.
keyMetrics.valMetricsDesc: Same metrics but on data the model hasn't trained on. Shows real-world performance.

charts.title: Charts and Visualizations
charts.description: Visual tools to understand model behavior:
charts.lossChart: Loss Over Epochs: Shows how loss decreased during training.
charts.accuracyChart: Accuracy Over Epochs: Shows learning progress for classification tasks.
charts.confusionMatrix: Confusion Matrix: Shows which classes the model confuses (for classification).
charts.rocCurve: ROC Curve: Measures the tradeoff between true positives and false positives.

interpreting.title: Interpreting Results
interpreting.tip1: Training and validation loss should both decrease - if validation increases, you're overfitting.
interpreting.tip2: A large gap between training and validation accuracy suggests overfitting.
interpreting.tip3: If both metrics are poor, try a more complex model or more training data.
interpreting.tip4: Early stopping shows if training ended before max epochs - this is usually good! Some charts or metric items may not appear for every model depending on the task and which metrics were selected.

overview.title: Inference Overview
overview.description: Inference is using your trained model to make predictions on new data. This is the payoff for all your work - now you can actually use your model!

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
prerequisites.req1: Training must be complete with status 'succeeded'.
prerequisites.req2: Your trained model must be available on the server.
prerequisites.req3: New data must have the same features (columns) as training data.

inputMethods.title: Input Methods
inputMethods.description: Two ways to provide data for predictions:
inputMethods.jsonDesc: Paste or type JSON directly. Good for testing with a few samples.
inputMethods.csvDesc: Upload a CSV file. Best for batch predictions on many samples.

howToUse.title: Making Predictions
howToUse.step1: Choose your input method (JSON or CSV).
howToUse.step2: Provide your data in the correct format - use the template buttons for help.
howToUse.step3: Enable 'Apply Normalization' if your training data was normalized.
howToUse.step5: Review results and download or copy as needed.

tips.title: Tips
tips.tip1: Feature order must match exactly what the model was trained on.
tips.tip2: For classification, results are probability arrays - highest value is the predicted class.
tips.tip3: Download the template to ensure your data format is correct.

loadModal.title: Load Saved Graph
loadModal.description: Select a previously saved network graph to load onto the canvas
loadModal.noGraphsHint: Create and save a graph to see it here
